reviewText:
You're probably well-familiar with the Hyperdimension franchise by now. Alongside Compile Heart's most popular RPG series, Idea Factory has commissioned the assistance of various developers, in order to produce spin-offs. It seems like every year, two or more Neptunia games are being released. Are we heading towards complete global saturation? It's too soon to tell. For now, let's look at the first spin-off to hit Steam: Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed. In the interest of sanity, I'm shortening the title to NepU for the remainder of the review.

NepU is by Tamsoft, the same developer responsible for the Onechanbara and Senran Kagura franchises. Those games are known for their fast-paced hack & slash action... among other things, but let's not get side-tracked just yet. Anyway, the plot of this game follows Famitsu and Dengikiko, two rival gaming-magazine writers looking for the next big story. Since Gamindustri revolves around the actions of the CPUs as well as the CPU Candidates, you can guess where this is going. Neptunia and company team up to complete quests and slash hundreds upon thousands of monsters.

Fans of Musou-styled games will feel right at home upon starting this one. Each quest consists of a small arena where monsters constantly spawn. By pressing the X and Y buttons, Nep & the gang perform a dizzying array of moves to decimate these hordes. There are also special attacks as well as HDD transformations for that touch of variety. For most quests, it's best to form a tag-team. Each of the 10 playable characters can team up, so if nothing else, you have Nepgear for backup in case Neptune takes a dirtnap. While I was playing Hyperdimension Action Neptune U, I was quite conflicted, on one hand I was nervous that someone would catch me playing the game. All hot blooded American males have been there, that extra sense  Spidey Sense you get during alone time  ahem, your vision becomes 20/20, you could hear a pin drop on a feather mattress, and your eyes fluctuate between the television and the door. Enough about my teen years, it's time to talk about HANU, a spin off of the popular Hyper dimension series of video games. The Story
The game takes place in a world known as Gamindustri  (Game Industry)  a world protected by divine  females known as CPU's or Console Patron Units... (Holy dang, a Central Processing unit, awesome) and their sisters the CPU candidates.  The game is situated after the previous games in a time of peace..  No major threats in sight boredom begins to reign supreme.  In an attempt to dispel the boredom two of the worlds leading journalist decide to write articles, Dengekiko decides to stick with the CPU's, she wants to write about them completing a series of quest and help bring the Goddesses extra fame and popularity.

Much like Dengekiko, the second Journalist Famitsu also wants to write an article about the CPU's but as an added twist she decides to focus on the CPU candidates, thinking that documenting the struggle of the candidates would make a far more interesting article.  Both groups head off to write their article.  Eventually after the rousing success of both ladies articles the news agency decides to have the two Journalist write another article, this time they join with the CPU and CPU candidates to take on a series of quest, the competition to see who can write the best article is on, and we as gamers are the winners because we get to play this amazing game.

Neptunia U is a Hack N' Slash, and is a spinoff of the Hyperdimension Neptunia franchise. It was originally released for the PS Vita.

The story is that Gamindustri is in a very peaceful state, so two journalists called Dengekiko and Famitsu (Based off real magazines in Japan) ask the CPUs and CPU candidates to do some quests that they planned to get a good story going. Afterwards, the gang just completes more and more quests for the journalists, but there's been a rapid increase in quests, and everything is not what it seems.

The story obviously isn't as rich or deep as the main series, but it still has a plentiful amount of cutscenes and the writing is still solid. However, it isn't a huge chunk of the game like the mainstream titles. Fans of the series will be pleased with it, even if it is a little shallow. Due to the game's simple plot and gameplay, you won't find anything too interesting to write home about. At least the character interactions are still as good as ever.

Plus, the English dub is 100% voiced acted; there are no missing voices in any cutscenes, unlike the Re;birth series. (If that's your preference.)



You can choose from 10 characters: The CPUs, the Candidates, Dengekiko and Famitsu. Each of them play a bit differently, and all have their own stats. For example, Uni has a rifle so she's most effective at mid-range and building her special ability, while Neptune does quick but weak melee attacks. It's mostly melee oriented, excluding Uni, Rom, and Ram. The character's melee attacks are different though; some of them hit hard but can't string combos very well, and some can do the opposite. Everyone has the same run speed. There's also equipment that the characters can equip, adding or taking away certain stats like defense and SP. You earn these by killing a certain number of a certain enemy.

Before we start, I'd like to inform you that this game is a spinoff, which means it's supposed to be made for Neptunia fans. If you are not a fan of this franchise and want to give it a try, then you should start with  Neptunia Re;Birth 1

Introducing
Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is the 3rd spinoff of the Neptunia franchise by Idea Factory, and the 4th game to be ported to PC. Unlike the Re;Birth games, this game is action-based (hence the title), so expect some confusions at first. I recommend you change the voice to Japanese to enjoy this game to the fullest.

GOOD elements of this game:
- Fresh and humourous atmosphere. Fortunately, this game retains a fresh and humourous appearance, which made the mainline Neptunia games. You will encounter many references, jokes, and 4th wall breaking moments in various characters, conversations, and even in-battle dialogues.
- Smooth, fast-paced hack n' slash gameplay. This is a Musou-type action game, so expect a gameplay similar to Sengan Kagura or Dynasty Warrior. Also this is a very good way to release stress.
- Pretty good music and sountracks. Personally I really liked the opening theme of the game (Venus no Harmonia - Asami Imai). The soundtracks include many tracks from the previous Neptunia games, and are pretty appropriate for an action game like this one.
- Excellent optimization. Recently, there are many bad PC ports by Japanese companies (Such as Naruto Storm 4, Tales of Symphonia, and Disgaea). However, IFI did a very appreciable work of optimizing this game, making it runs fluently even on a 5-year-old PC. Basically, if your PC can play Rebirth 1, then it can max this out at ease.
- Some best-looking badges that I've ever seen.

AVERAGE or DEBATABLE elements of this game:
- Many fanservice elements . Personally, I have no problem with fanservice, especially when it appears in a spinoff. Anyway, you can turn it off completely after a few battles, if you don't want it.
- Pretty limited customization. For each character, there are about 3 weapons, 3 skills, a few costumes and a fixed combo set; which is nowhere as near as mainline Neptunia games.
- No mouse support, and you cannot change music in battle

BAD elements of this game:
- The plot is half-baked. I'm not gonna spoil anything here. This is generally a problem for spinoffs, but I'm sure they can do it better.
- Quests can be repetitive and grindy after a long time of playing. For this problem, I advise that you should do a quest several times with different characters, and shouldn't play it too much in a day.
- Textures and sprites are extremely low-res. You'll notice this immediately if you've played Re;Birth 3, or if you trigger a Costume Break with Vert.

Conclusion:
Despite having a weak plot and a flawed quest system,  Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed still contains many humour layers, plus a smooth and flexible combat system that any Neptunia fans out there will enjoy. Also, a thumb-up for Idea Factory International for making such a good port.
I give this game a 6.5 overall, and a 7.5 in its Anime category.
For Neptunia fans out there, I recommend getting this game on a sale (probably bigger than 50%). For anyone else interested in this franchise, I recommend that you should start with Re;Birth 1. If you've read up to this point, I'm sure you will like it.

reviewText:
Introduction
Diverging from the Japanese style Role-Playing Game nature of the previous Re;Birth entries in the Hyperdimension Neptunia series currently available on Steam, Hyperdimention Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is a Hack and Slash Action game. You will fight unyielding hordes of enemies simultaneously until the conditions of your current mission are satisfied. Set in a video game consoles inspired world, you will find many enjoyable references to other video games scattered throughout as you play.

Gameplay
The game revolves around controlling one character at time on missions that take place in an arena like field. In most cases an optional second character can be waiting in the wings to take over for the current character if need be. Each mission has a success condition that must be met before the event is allowed to end. Typically, a mission involves killing unending throngs of monsters and often includes a few bosses sprinkled in for good measure. Since you are just one character, you have a number of abilities to help you achieve success. There is the normal attack, which is very effective in its own right, the heavy attack that is generally much more effective than the normal attack but has a drawback. Heavy attack helps to damage your costume each time you use it. Using these two types of attacks together allows you to make powerful combos. There are also special abilities that each character possesses that can really help turn the tide of battle in their favour. Once you have either been damaged enough or have done enough damage, a super powered option (HDD) becomes available. The HDD powered option is something like a new character entering the field.  It shares most of the same abilities as the character that summoned it but all of which are far more powerful than the normal version of them.

A battle damaged costume on a character reduces their defense but increases the rate in which their super power charges up. It‚Äôs a trade off but since the super power versions is significantly more powerful, it is generally worth it to let the costume become ruined through the over use of powerful attacks. If you prefer to make the game more challenging there is an unlockable outfit that can‚Äôt be damaged thus reducing the rate in which the super power charges. There is also the ability to start the round with the costume already damaged thus making your life more difficult early on as you wait for the super power to charge.

The majority of the game is spent on missions either doing them for the first time or repeating them to farm medals from the monsters found in that particular mission. Medals are used to unlock new weapons, power ups, and equipment in order to aid you to complete the more difficult missions. You will find yourself grinding away for them to some degree. Some monsters are common enough that you will hit the 999 cap without needing to farm them, others show up less often so you may have to actively hunt them down in old missions. Luckily missions can be completed rather quickly so it isn‚Äôt that painful to grind a mission repeatedly. This is especially true if you are supremely overpowered for that particular mission.

The charming mystery story of Hyperdimension Neptunia U revolves around two Gameindustri Journalists trying to outdo each other by getting the better scoop. They follow the CPUs (Console Patron Units) and CPU Candidates around out in the field trying to get material and images for their respective magazine articles and news reports. If you are a fan of visual novels or other games that put more emphasis on story and less on actual gameplay, Hyperdimension Neptunia U should be right up your alley. The game often finds itself broken off into long conversions taking place among a selection of the ten characters in-between missions. For the most part, the missions themselves really have no impact on the story and are just used as a device to transition between dialogues. There is nothing really wrong with this though as the fully voiced dialogues between the characters are almost always very humourous and fun to listen to. The way the characters interact with each other and have their own playful rivalries and friendships going on makes the game feel alive. There is no real method to impact on the conversations though so if you were to replay the game, you would hear the same dialogues each time. There are no prompts to select a topic or idea for them to discuss. You are really playing more of a passive role during these times.

Overall Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is a game that should satisfy Hyperdimension Neptunia fans as they get to interact with their favourite CPUs again and hear more of their story. Albeit, it is a story set in an alternate dimension and not considered cannon to the rest of the Hyperdimension Neptuna story. For people who like Visual Novels or Arena style Action battle games, Hyperdimension Neptunia U is a great place to get into the Hyperdimension Neptunia universe. There is a lot of story to enjoy without a lot of gameplay/questing getting in the way of it although there is no real way to drive the story yourself. If you are classic JRPG fan you may not like Hyperdimension Neptunia U as much as you would the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth series, which is an excellent series in its own right and you owe it to yourself to check it out.

Pros:The Hyperdimention Neptunia characters are back in an all new game
While not as long as the Re;Birth series, U is a very lengthy game
The characters feel alive, as if you are actually listening into potential real life conversations among friends
Great Visual effects and accompanying Audio. The characters are all well detailed including some interesting ‚Äúfan service‚Äù thrown in there as well if you are into that sort of thing
Fully voice acted
The controls work great for this game. Very fluid and easy to control. Making a combo doesn‚Äôt involve memorizing tons of nerve racking key presses in advance
The idea that costumes can be damaged by the enemies attacks and through wear and tear makes for a more realistic element in the game
Unlockable content that helps make the game more enjoyable and stretches out gameplay
Paid DLC are reasonably priced for what they give

Cons:Missions are very repetitive and not overly challenging once you get the hang of them. They feel like they were just thrown in as an afterthought to help break up the story a bit
There is no story during a mission and the characters frequently repeat the same phrases to each other
Combat is repetitive
Since you have little impact to the story yourself, there is no real draw to replay it right away. Since it is a long game, I am perfectly fine with that, but it could be a negative to others who enjoy seeing multiple stories unfold in one game
Achievements are a real grind fest
Recommendation
Despite the fact combat and missions are repetitive, the mysterious and charming story behind Hyperdimention Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is enough to keep you wanting more. If you are a fan of the Hyperdimention Neptunia series, go for it, you likely won‚Äôt regret it. If you are new to the series and a JRPG fan, I‚Äôd say start with the Re;Birth series and then get U to enjoy more story related to your new found friends. If you are a fan of Bullet Hell style games where you are massively outnumbered and are fighting to survive, you likely would love U if you equip the forced Level 1 only accessory. Go ahead, give it a go!

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is a whole new different approach to a Hyperdimension series. Instead of a visual novel JRPG we are being served a non-canon hack n' slash game with characters from the mentioned series.

About the game itself:As a huge fan of the franchise, i've had a really good time playing the game with my beloved characters. I'm surprised how well it fit into my tastes. However, this game is not perfect. As long as i really enjoyed the time spent with it, the game is repetitive and does not really offer anything challenging throughout it. It's a casual game.

Enemies do not differ too much from each other. There are different types of them with different attacks, but you won't notice it because they will swarm you and you will keep smashing buttons anyway, so it does not matter in the long run.

Different characters have different attack patterns and different combos in different forms, which is really nice, it makes the game more fun to play if you really want to get the most of it. Game allows you to choose gear for your characters with medals which you drop from enemies. You can exchange them for gear or stat bonuses. There are different ways to build your equipment and some of them are interesting, such as a 9000 attack but 1 defense build. Oh, and there is fanservice in this game. However, you can make it appear more often, choose already ripped off clothes or turn it off at all. It's up to your tastes. I guess.

However, grinding for achievements in this game might be the worst of them all so far. It's boring. You have to clear a 50 floor tower 5 times with different characters and clear some kind of battleground with every character in the game (which is not that bad, actually). The rest of the achievements is based story-wise, so you get them while playing.

In short, the game is good, but you might not like it if you are not familiar with the franchise. My first playthrough took me around 17 to 18 hours and there is a lot to do after the story mode. The game is simply fun, but i would not recommend buying it at full price. I'm not saying it's not worth it, but 28 euro is a little too much for a spin-off title which offers half of the gameplay time of the previous games.

TL;DR
Pros:+More nep
+Brings characters to life even more than before
+Different combos for every character
+There is what to do after finishing the story mode

Medium:+Fanservice
-Fanservice

Cons:-Repetitive gameplay
-Achievement grinding is really grindy

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the 'Warriors/Mosuo' series for almost 15 years now. It has become something of a trend in recent years for all manner of series to have their own 'Warriors' spin-off.
When it came to Neptunia's hack and slash spin-off, I anticipated something along the lines of the 'Dynasty Warriors: Gundam' series; lots of characters from the Neptunia francise, with the Lily Rank system following along the lines of DW:G3's operator system.
To put it simply, I expected to have more than ten characters; I was at least hoping a few Makers would be featured in this game. Perhaps it was naive of me to expect Compile Heart/Idea Factory to actually put some effort into their games, but I was trying to be optimistic about this game.
All that said, however, I was not massivly disappointed with this spin-off. The characters all use their Hyperdimension designs and personalities, all the CPUs are given some respect (even the Candidates, who seem to have become the series' chew toys as of late), there's around 10-15 hours of gameplay if you simply plough through it all, and the Lily Rank system was more fleshed out and entertaining than usual, with short voice clips available between all characters as their ranks go up.
Characters are hardly balanced, gameplay-wise. Vert is insanly mobile; Uni, Rom and Ram are highly mobile with long range attacks. This makes them more effective for most of the game, while Blanc and Noire are basically useless. Fortunatly, while Purple Heart is not as mobile as Vert, and Purple Sister use melee instead of ranged attacks, the Nep sisters are easily the most powerful characters(as they damn well should be.)
I do appreciate that the designers bothered to make character designs and movests for Denkiko and Famistu(both of whom were previously Chirper-only characters) however, I was left to wonder why IF and Compa, who do appear in this game, are not playable. Again, this links back into the overall lack of Human characters here, but why put them in the game in the first place if you won't allow me to play as them?
Overall, it's a decent hack and slash. Just don't expect too much from it, and try and purchase it while it's on sale.

reviewText:
Not a bad game. As you might already know, the game is a spin off of the Hyperdimension RPGs. It plays like a mix of a Dinasty Warriors game and a tower arena game. It even does have a tower arena mode. I feel it could have been much more, though. Even if you try to balance thing out, as in, not getting your characters too overpowered, most enemies just stand still staring at you as you wack them with whatever attack you toss at them. As enemies go, the selection is as wacky as those found in the RPGs. From cats to penguins to dog headed jellies and even walking visual novel panels.

This game could have also benefited from a vs pvp online mode as it does already have the base for such outings. It has a stage that reminds me a lot of the Dragon Ball tournament arenas. Sure, it would have also needed proper skill balance between characters. Character selection is decent, but after awhile you will feel like you do the same with all of them. Your only options in the end are ranged or melee, cone AOE or centered AOE. There's also a cloth rip mechanic that acts as a buff at the cost of some defense. I personally felt the mechanic unnecessary. These are not really the kind of characters I'd prefer to see semi naked. They are just too much on the cute side for that(for my taste at least). Thankfully, as you progress through the game you can chose to either keep the mechanic, or wear unbreakable outfits, or wear an always torn outfit.

The game also has cheats you unlock as you complete things. While optional, activating them do not prevent you from doing achievements. Sure, this is helpful for the one very grindy achievement of filling all of the characters Lily friendship levels. Something that becomes very boring because of the game's lack of variety.

Now, the things that do save this game and make me recommend it are the characters themselves. If you don't know what Hyperdimension is all about, the characters represent video game consoles of the modern era, like Playstation and XBox. Much of the dialogue is funny enough to cause chuckles. Though I lament that this game lacks more of these dialogues, like it's RPG counterparts. So even though I recommend this one,, you should go for the RPGs if you really want to enjoy funny comments and cameos.

All in all, this is a game that's not bad, but could have been much more. Pick it up when on discount.

I bought this game just kinda hoping for a game to hack n' slash away and random shet because why not, and I ended up being pleasantly surprised.
I'd always see the games in this series pop up on steam but never bothered (personally not a turn-based kinda person), but a few days ago I saw this as a new release and just clicked on it, and found it was an action-y spin off of that one series I keep seeing everywhere. Look up some things on the game and thought it looked really fun, so I bought it.
From my understanding, this series is an RPG series set to kinda make fun of the gaming industry, and contains many subtle-and not so subtle-nods to things (i.e characters named Famitsu and Dengekiko) and such, and, well..

wao

So, what I really liked about this game is the fluent combat and the extremely colorful visuals, as well as the pretty cool characters (my fav character is probably Neptune, but my fav character to play as is Famitsu). The voice acting is pretty good, the dialogue and such is entertaining, the music is pretty cool and I like the change of tone when you transform into your HDD mode, and overall the game is quite fun to play. There's some pretty good character customization for each character and all characters except for Famitsu and Dengekiko start with 2-3 different outfit colors & hair colors for their normal and HDD forms, but you gain more weapons and such over time of playing.

But there are quite a few things that I absolutely hated about this game or just really didn't like; I feel like the sound design is absolutely terrible sometimes, most characters don't feel like they do much to enemies - like you're wacking things with nerf swords (with the exception of Dengekiko, Famitsu, and Blanc), some special attacks don't have sound effects or sound bland and boring even though they look flashy and cool af, and sometimes the enemies are a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. There've been multiple occasions where I'd get trapped in a circle of enemies that relentlessly obliterate both my characters in seconds without any hope of escaping. Also, sometimes it feels like the characters are really unbalanced, like how ranged characters transformed into their HDD mode are pretty much untouchable in most occasions. There isn't much of a story, but from what I've gathered, the main series has a much more involved story than this spin-off. One more thing, the combos feel a little strict and you won't find yourself straying from the same combos sometimes. Oh yeah, and there's a weird slow down when your framerate drops under 60FPS (don't worry, the game is reltatively easy to run, just run on lower resolution and/or windowed mode)

IN CONCLUSION:

-Pretty visuals & flashy attacks and skills
-Cool and relatively interesting characters

Overall, I feel this was one of the best games on steam that I've bought in quite a while.

The story is simple. Two characters by the name of Dengekiko (Based on Dengeki magazines) and Famitsu (Based on Weekly Famitsu magazines) are having a battle for best reporter and best articles on the Gamindustri CPUs and CPU candidates. Soon something fishy happens and it's up to the total of Ten characters to find out what's wrong and save Gamindustri... again.

With writing this simplistic, it has to have a lot of charm, right? Yes. The charm of the characters shines as usual. The humor is well done as you hear lots of funny lines from the characters. Often making video game references and jokes. If you're firmiliar with the humor in Nep Nep games, you'll enjoy it even here.



Now onto the gameplay. Is it good? Well yeah. It's pretty good but it definitely still has that Portable Game feel with short, easy to do quests and repetitive actions. Not that it's a bad thing. This simplicity makes the game PERFECT for quick play without struggle. Not overly hard and satisfying when you get a long combo string going.  Each character handling pretty well despite a couple handling the exact same way.

reviewText:
A Review On Hyperdimension Neptunia U Rating: 9/10
This was all around a great game. It's right down the alley for old fans of the series and new people who saw it pop up in their recommended list.

Gameplay
Unlike the previous turn-based combat of the rest of the franchise to this date, Neptunia U takes the hack n' slash route of RPGs. Combat in Neptunia U is extremely satisfying for a few hours, but then kind of loses its novelty after that period of time. Eventually you find a broken combo on a broken CPU, say Blanc, and spam her X+X+X+X+Y+Y combo which absolutely destroys and nothing really happens, not to mention the CPUs and Candidates are nowhere close to being equal in strength, and here's a breakdown of their power.

1. Neptune: She's the original MC of the series. Her X combo whilst in HDD does this insane AOE spin attack that destroys, whilst her non HDD form is simply forward directional attacks. Nothing special.
2. Noire: One of my favorite characters, she is surprisingly less powerful than I expected. Whilst she can go toe to toe against most enemies, her Y, which is her few AOE wave clear attacks takes a while to set up, making her damage output less that some other characters'.
3. Blanc: Some people hate on Blanc for having slow attacks, but on the contrary, her mobility combo in HDD of X+X+X+X+Y+Y makes her near untouchable and can deal 4000+ damage a hit at level 35. Blanc, at that point, is absolutely broken.
4. Vert: One of the most OP characters, her Y combos in the middle of her X combos allows her to dash from place to place, making Vert unhittable.
5. Nepgear: Her skill set is quite the same as Neptune's in HDD, but in her regular form, her X combo can extend a Y at the end which functions as a dash, much like Vert.
6. Uni, AKA Skillshot God: Why is Uni called this? Well, all her attacks are very directional. Her Ys are, most of her Xs are, and in HDD, every single attack points at the first direction the first attack goes, especially in her X combo, allowing you to move and kite every single enemy, point the gun at them, and spam. Her Y is also broken AF but takes an insane amount of time to charge up, rendering it useless when she's crowded.
7. Rom and Ram, AKA Spam Gods: I'm lumping them together due to their similar movesets. Most of their Xs in HDDs are directional, and the Ys are basically spam damage-all-enemies-in-a-huge-cone type attacks.
8. Dengekiko and Famitsu: Wow, are these 2 journalists underpowered. I mean, I swear nobody uses them unless they have to. Their basics are weak, they have no mobility or surround AOE except for Dengekiko's Ys in combo with Xs or out.

And of course, every Neptunia game has some broken item. In Neptunia 1, it was probably the Stamina Band that gave you 5000 extra health, in Neptunia 2 it was the FREE Gehaburn for Nepgear that let you one-shot every monster for at least 30 levels. In this game, it's that Scrambler Drive that allows you to, get this, instantly HDD at the beginning of every game. Couple that with the HDD gained from Costume Break, It essentially allows for each character you bring in to use their BROKEN AF EXE Drive twice. Wow.

Story
For all of you long-time fans out there, you all know that Neptunia is a story-centered game. This game is chock full of the standard Neptunia humor. For all of you noobs out there, that includes the boob jokes, RIP Blanc Forever ;(, classic 4th wall breaks, which Idea Factory did a great job with, and the general personality of your favorite characters. However, the story is stretched a bit thin. The Quests" in the game are the same thing

Finally, Neptunia spin-offs are starting to appear on steam. What that means is:

Story

Right of the bat the game informs you that it's a spin-off and the story is non-canon.
Despite that the cast is still the same good ol' CPU goddesses and their sisters. They are accompanied by two journalists Dengekiko and Famitsu, and together they try to uncover a new Scoop. Yup, that's pretty much the entire plot.

The story's quite short, and unless you're playing the game once a week or so, you'll finish it in a jiffy.

Gameplay

reviewText:
We need less goddamit! LESS IS MORE!
Finally, Neptunia spin-offs are starting to appear on steam. What that means is:
1. More games for the fans and newcomers.
2. ...Let's face it you're all here for the animu fanservice, aren't ya?

Story

Right of the bat the game informs you that it's a spin-off and the story is non-canon.
Despite that the cast is still the same good ol' CPU goddesses and their sisters. They are accompanied by two journalists Dengekiko and Famitsu, and together they try to uncover a new Scoop. Yup, that's pretty much the entire plot.

The story's quite short, and unless you're playing the game once a week or so, you'll finish it in a jiffy.

Gameplay

As stated before, this is a spin-off. Instead of a JRPG, NepU is an Action Beat-'em-Up with RPG elements, it's quite fun. The controls are fluid. Characters have special skills, combos, transformations (just like before) , though the amount of combos could have been more varied.

The game also features the Costume Break" system. It gives the characters a boost in stats... and it's for fanservice purposes too: get hit enough times and your controlled characters will get their costumes ripped to shreds with only a few scraps left to cover the goodies. Depending on whether you like the cutesy characters running around almost naked it's a hit or miss. Luckily the feature can be disabled midgame for those who don't like it.

Graphics and Sounds

The game retains what is great about the previous Neptunia games - the colorful atmosphere

reviewText:
Fun Hack and Slash take on the Hyperdimension Neptunia series. Sorta like the Dynasty Warriors games in which you fight hoards of weak enemies and then take on a stronger boss enemy. You know the deal. Lots of combos and special attacks. Has the HDD mode from the other games and ultimate attacks which are very nice to look at. There are a lot of extras as well like items to unlock, music mode, a pause menu that lets you rotate and zoom the camera to get that ideal screenshot of the action. Just an enjoyable experience all around.

I am not even super into the series myself. Didn't even finish the first game even. But I did like the characters and the VN sections. I just could not get into the combat and slow pace of the game. Specifically the weird positioning in combat and the grinding. But this game kept all the good stuff and got rid of the boring combat! Luckily this is just a spinoff that can be enjoyed on its own. So if you want a little anime hack and slash action go ahead and check this out. It has fully voiced VN sections and Fun combat.

Negatives would be the lack of graphics options. This is a Vita port though so it shouldn't be too hard to run or anything. But it would have been nice to have the basic graphics options for a PC game. I had another negative but I forgot what it is. I will edit later if I remember.

Side note. The clothes tearing isn't such a big deal. Some people may be put off by it though. There is a way to get rid of it but you have to get beat up a few times before you unlock the unbreakable outfit. I don't even really notice it myself. You get the little splash when it happens then its business as usual. And the after battle close up but its like dude this series always had fanservice.

reviewText:
So i just beat this game, and here's my checklist for whether or not you will want this game.

You will like this game if:
-You were/are a fan of the hyperdimension neptunia series
-You like Dynasty warriors/ Hyrule warriors eseque gameplay
-You aren't looking for a particularly in depth story
-You want to turn your brain off, bash some trash mobs and listen to the BGM
-Idk, maybe your just here for the fanservice, which is literally just canned stripping animations and less clothing

You will not like this game if:
-You are looking for a game that has any sort of replayability or multiple endings(only has one ending)
-You are looking for a game that is long-lasting or has varied gameplay (game lasts about 14hours if you do all of the side missions, around 8 if you just bum rush the main story)
-You are looking for a good hack-n-slash game. Its an average hack-n-slash game with a plethora of colors and like a hundred enemies on the screen at any given time
-You are looking for a challenging video game. You could probably beat this game whilst playing tetris.

Alright, now on to the actual reveiw, which  will include more specifics on what the game does, how it is similar and differnt to the main game series, writing style, and other random gripes and praises. Warning: Word soup ahead

Review
First off, the main allure of every hyperdimension neptunia game is the characters, as they are fairly quirky and funny takes on various sterotypes and are generally quite funny. This game... it seems to have forgotten part of that, as eveything that makes the characters who they are is dulled out a little bit presumably because there is less dialouge to work with, meaning the character's individual personalities are shown 75% less and instead is replaced by inter-character interactions... Which would be great if only there was, i don't know, an actual REASON for the characters to interact? like a conflict of interest? or literally anything other than a random string of jokes, compliments and backhanded insults? A huge part of what made following the character development in the main games was the fact that they were faced by a tangible conflict in the form of other characters and subsequently overcame that and became friends/ tentative allies. This game has none of that and instead mostly replaces it with proof of character relation, which basically means the games spends a lot of time talking about how the characters interact with each other, but in a very one-directional way. so yeah thats my veiw on the overall writing style and no, i'm not going to comment on the fact that some of the lines are literally just super-cringeworthy memes. Moving on, the next thing i found intruiging is how they modifyed all of the assets from the main game( everything from game mechanics to maps) and how some of it was good, some of it just weird. The good part is that they made all of the various stats streamlined AF so you dont really have to think to hard about your strategy for hitting things, as well as the way the various meters(SP and EXE) are made easy to manage in a 3d fast-paced game enviroment. I also really like how they did the menus: if i needed to check something, it took like 3 clicks tops. Now the weird parts  are the map implementation and the enemy aggro mechanic. The maps are pretty much copy-paste from the main games, except they added barriers that basicly just railroad you down a single path, which would be fine if these maps served as awesome arenas, but they dont(in fact in some cases you wonder how in the world your supposed to fight in such cramped spaces). However, this problem is partially alleviated due to the inclusion of a few actual arena levels with lots of space, which i thought were the most enjoyable levels. Second flaw is kinda minor in that the enemy aggro ranges dont work right half the time, they suffer from the same problem the enemies in the main series did in that if you do anything but walk in a straight line they lose sight of you and just sit there for like a whole 5 seconds before noticing you again. Again, minor problem that only really presents itself if you try and kite a group for a mass wipeout. Next up, character imbalance, which i realize has existed in the past games and directly corellated with the characters confidence/skillset(which was awesome by the way) but it just doesn't mesh well in the genre because you cant have the party protect the weak character anymore, they are at the mercy of stun-locks and crazy high dps and there isn't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you can do about it. You know why you're here so I won't waste time.

Some Facts
A Neptunia-themed arena-based hack 'n slash game. A port of the Vita game. All characters have light/strong attacks, aerial combos, special attacks (a.k.a SP Skills), and a temporary transformation ability (HDD/CPU mode) which changes up some moves and increases the character's power and survivability. Characters may use a powerful super ability (EXE Drive) once transformed which will revert them to their regular state. You build SP and meter by landing attacks. You usually have to kill everything in an arena to win. You can take two characters into battle and swap between them as necessary. The game encourages you to swap by filling the transformation meter of the inactive character first, then for the active character.

The playable characters are the CPUs who have CPU Candidates, and the CPU Candidates themselves, plus Famitsu and Dengekiko. Characters gain EXP and level up, increasing their stats. Killing monsters nets you medals for each type of monster (Dogoo, Pixelvader, etc.) which you can trade in for permanent stat boosts, equippable stat items, or weapons. Also, as two characters complete battles, their friendship rank (Lily Rank) goes up, conferring bonuses to each character. You also get costumes, and a sound test mode.

reviewText:
I'll give the short summary first.
In case anyone isn't familiar, this isn't a title made by the usual HDN folks, but rather a project farmed out to Tamsoft. So, if you're looking for a quick summary of what the game is, expect it to play like a less polished Senran Kagura game that's gone through a HDN reskin, yet doesn't have any of HDN's writing and humor chops.
Now, if you are a HDN fan and are looking for a button mash-y hack-n-slash game that you can pick up once in a while for half an hour to an hour and put right back down, presuming you can get this game on a sale and can put up with the awful camera controls, this will be a great fit.

--

Now, for a more thorough examination.

Pros:
-The combat is simple and straightforward. Mashing light attack and occasionally popping off a special move will get you through basically the whole game, which is great, if all you want to do is unwind and turn off your brain.
-On most missions, you are free to play as your favorite combination of CPU and/or CPU Candidate. Nepgear and Rom? Vert and Uni? Neptune and Blanc? Go nuts!
-The title runs perfectly fine and supports full 1080p. It also seems to control just fine with either keyboard or controller (note: I've only used my 360 pad. I presume it has solid DirectInput support since the games hail from Sony consoles, but I'm not 100% sure).
-All quests list their level requirements, so you'll know if you're about to get some much needed stress relief out of colorful monsters or be pounded into mulch.

Cons:
-The writing and humor. I don't know if it's just bad writing or a localization issue from the game being caught in the petticoats of the western nanny-states, but... Based on my experience with the HDN series, this was a big beacon that this was handled by someone else. If you've ever played a Senran Kagura game, it's about on par with that. If you haven't, just pretend that there is no story.
-I know that character balance isn't very big in hack-n-slash titles, but... There are certain characters that you'll bring out for certain quests and otherwise never touch again.
-Maybe, I'm just spoiled by the PC ports made by IF and Compile Heart, but... Somehow, the options menu is inferior to what you usually see on Vita or 3DS titles. Yes, you get windowed, fullscreen, and borderless windowed support up to 1080p, but... There's nothing above that, there's no graphical options what's-so-ever, and there isn't even an option to toggle how quickly you want the text to be displayed on the screen and are locked to the slowest pace in existence.
-My biggest gripe of all, though, is the camera. First of all, it drunkenly swings around, with the options making it far too rigid or much too loose. Also, unlike the other HDN titles I've played, there's no way to zoom the camera out, so I hope that you like having your camera be close enough to your character's head that you may as well be able to reach in and pick bits of dandruff out of their hair.

reviewText:
I haven't completed the game yet, so I can't comment on the whole plot, but I've seen enough to get a general idea about this game.

First off, the gameplay is really good. A bit hard to begin with, because it's not the same type as the re;birth series, but you learn pretty fast how to control the characters. Since it's a hack'n slash, fights are really fluid. You don't have to wait for your turn, and it surpringly works really well on my computer while I have the lowest configuration (I can easily reach 60 FPS, while I had to stick with 15-20 in Re;Birth 2). Of course, you can only control one character at a time, but again the fluidity helps you get over it, and fights quickly become easy to handle.

Secondly, the characters. Such a pleasure to see again all the CPUs and CPU Candidates, with their usual talks and personalities (I wouldn't have mind seeing more of Blanc's cute persona). And a big plus since the game is FULLY voiced in English. No scene with only Japanese voices or no voices at all, you can enjoy hearing English. I don't mind Japanese voices, but the community was eagerly waiting for something like this.

Thirdly, the graphics. It's not meant to be realist, and it's better that way. Mainly because a Neptunia game drawn like The Last of Us or Uncharted 4 would look strange, but also because it keep with the anime environment. And you can really see it improved through the game, with amazingly drawn curves (Not those ones) and shapes, rendering a really pretty world with no angle where there should not be any.

Fourthly, the audio. Again, wonderful musics that fits well with the scenes, the environments and the characters. We can hear again some musics from the previous games, as well as a few new ones. And that opening is AMAZING.

Yeah, I know, I can't end it without speaking of the main selling point of the game, if you haven't heard about it you're probably going out too much, It's the best idea in the world : Ripping-off clothes when you get hurts too much. With a possibility to unlock unbreakable clothes, easily breakable ones and already ripped-off clothes. BEST. IDEA. EVER. I-it's not like that's what made me buy it or anything... Baka!

Jokes aside, I shall give that game an average score of 9.5/10

reviewText:
Fans of Hyperdimension Neptunia will be expecting their favourite characters to duke it out against recognisable enemies. Those fans won't be disappointed. You can choose from the main CPU's and their candidates (poor candidate-less Vert) as they battle in a Dynasty Warriors-esque spin on the franchise.

Special skills are unleashed via a pop-up menu accessed on a button press (controller recommended here), with your SP displayed as little blue pills in your status bar. Each pill represents 1000 SP, and each skill consumes a multiple of 1000 so it's a resource you'll run out of quicky. Fret not, however, as the enemies will often drop Hero Drinks which replenish your HP and restore some vital SP.

You can choose up to two characters per battle. One character will fight and the other recovering HP in the background, which you can switch at will. All characters have a transformation or 'HDD' mode true to the original games, which vastly increases your stats and even changes your skills in some cases. Use of this mode requires you to fill an 'EXE' guage which fills faster if your character is out of combat.

Getting hit results in damage to whatever outfit you happen to be wearing. This means two separate sets of damage, both for your standard outfit and HDD modes. The exception to this are the two journalists, Dengekiko and Famitsu who use the same outfit for both modes as they don't have a 'true' HDD mode.

Destroying your outfit means taking more damage overall, but heavier hits and more chances to fill the EXE bar, which means more opportunity for unleashing HDD mode. In addition, the EXE bar also grants you a super move which can empty an entire room and demolish boss monsters in mere moments. This can be used in HDD mode as well for a truly devastating attack, though it drains the EXE bar and you will revert back to normal afterwards.

In addition to the action, there is plenty of voice work the fan favourite VA's from franchise. For me, just listening to their banter is as entertaining as the action itself as they constantly break the 4th wall and make subtle and not-so subtle references to other video game franchises.

It's hard not to recommend the game. It knows exactly who it's target audience is and gives them what they want. Newcomers to the series might feel a bit lost and won't understand some of the references made (some refer to prior Hyperdimension games) but can enjoy it for what it is. A quirky action game with a healthy dose of humour to keep you entertained.

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U is an unusually low quality game for the series. If you hadn't already guessed, this game is a Dynasty Warriors-esque game where you need to mow down waves of enemies to win. But the game lacks even the most basic features anyone has come to expect from the Hack and Slash genre.

The main problem is that the game never tries to do anything more than that. DW and every variation at least has some variation on killing enemies - your objective is rarely just 'Kill 1000 dudes': they're far more often to the effect of capturing areas, defending teammates or killing key enemies to push the battle in your favor in sprawling maps where there's plenty to do. As it turns out being stuck in a claustrophobic space with no reason to do anything other than spam your light attack gets boring real fast.

And that's quite the issue. The game never requires you to do anything other than spam one button. Even in the most basic of this genre, considering whether to use a single or multi-target move or expend a special bar is always present. But here, using anything but the patented 'spam x' strategy is horrendously inefficient. You might question the use of efficient in a context like this, but it will be at the forefront of your mind when playing this game. There is an ungodly amount of grinding. If you want to complete this game, you will need to grind. Each. And. Every. Character. There is no catch up mechanic. The only way to level those character you don't want to play but have to is to find yourself a nice long mission with lots of enemies and switch your brain off for a few hours.

In addition, the game seems to have a hard time conveying itself to the player. There are numerous points which are scarcely explained or expanded upon. Quite often I had found myself in a mission killing hundreds of enemies only to grind to a scrreching halt as only one enemy appeared on the map. In order to complete the mission I had to defeat the last 50 enemies one by one. These were also bosses so they took at least a minute to kill. This turned a five minute mission in a twenty minute mission that was painful to play. Even after searching all over the (very small) map for additional enemies, there was nothing. I refuse to believe the devs were genuinely incompetent enough to consider this sort of thing a mechanic, so I can only assume this was a glitch.

For some reason there is also no autosave. Maybe in the hopes you'll accidently erase your progress and waste more time?

Too much of this game feels like cheap padding to push the playtime of the game upwards to justify its price tag. Unfortunately the core mechanics are far too barren to even consider it. Ultimately there is no reason to enjoy this game: the graphics are upscaled vita models, the soundtrack is tiny, the gameplay is incredibly boring with zero depth or interesting mechanics and the story is hardly interesting enough to justify the slog. If you're interested in a Hack and Slash, try Dynasty Warriors 8, Pirate Warriors 3 or Hyrule Warriors. All three are far more developed and interesting than this game.

TL:DR, looks good, plays good, runs well, is a bit shallow, but worth your time.
A muso game with the Naptunia asthetic. While it is a decent game, it's fairly shallow. There are only three specials available at any given time, plus an ultimate, and another three in a different character transformation. You can switch between two chosen characters, and I feel an opportunity was missed to have character switch combos. Combos themselves are pretty basic, nothing fancy and no combo creating, but that would be asking a bit too much.
Enemies are sometimes too large in number, spawning constantly as the only type in numbers of around six, slowing down the action a lot. Doesn't happen often, but happens.
Story is a Neptunia plot, works well, is generally fun and well voice acted.
Looks pretty good, no port problems. Runs smooth.
There's even more fanservice than usual, but I really don't mind.
There are ten characters, and most of them feel pretty similar. Uni has a really interesting moveset, since she uses a gun instead of a melee weapon, but there's usually a spin, a slam, a stinger, and a launcher.
Difficulty isn't that high. There are a few situations where you get destroyed pretty quickly, but it's not a problem if you know what you're doing.
If you've never played a muso, you've played them and you like them, you like Neptunia, or any combo thereof, pick it up. It's fun enough, and I'm easily going to finish it.

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that I'm heading into this, having only experienced HDN Re;birth 1 and 2 and nothing else. So, if it seems like I'm giving this game too much (or, too little) credit due to not being familiar with the rest of the series, my apologies.
Now, on paper, this game seems great. A hack-n-slash game based in the HDN universe? Even if it's simplistic, how could this go wrong? Unfortunately, there's a few minor things that make it a less-than-pleasant experience. Mind you, they can (and, I'm expecting, will) be patched, but... In the present, this feels like a less polished version of a Senran Kagura game.

--

Edit: So, it turns out that this was literally made by Tamsoft. That explains the odd feel of the game as well as the differences with the other HDN games.
Anyway. I came here to drop a bit of an update, having played more of the game. Here's the thing. The loose camera is still a problem. The field of view is still annoying and lets enemies come up behind you, unseen. Still, if you can deal with those issues and you want a game that you can pick up for half an hour once in a while, play for a bit, and drop, it's pretty good, if a bit expensive. Otherwise, as I initially said, don't bother.

--

On the bright side, the port seems solid. Now, I know that unlike the likes of Koei Tecmo, Idea Factory and Compile Heart are (in my experience) known for making quite solid ports, but I always feel the need to point this out. The game appears to be stable, has the full range of resolutions, has proper full screen AND borderless windowed mode, and even goes as far as full button remapping...the whole nine. No complaints there.

Unfortunately, everything else, requires commentary.
-First and foremost, the camera. It is both, quite loose and has a very narrow field of view. The former, may be fixed with a simple slider bar over the three options, as the jump between nearly immobile Slow and Average is massive. The latter....dear god, please let us zoom out. As close as the camera is to the back of the characters' heads, I can basically start counting their dandruff flakes.
-The combat, while quite mash-y, it certainly works well enough. Its combo system is very basic and won't exactly have the complexity of Phantom Beaker: Battle Grounds' combat system. I'm not saying that's bad. Just keep that in mind, if you have the preference for something more complex.
-The story....what happened? Did someone run out of ideas while having to meet a deadline? Or, is it a localization issue? I know that story isn't exactly the big selling point of a HDN game, but... In the Re;birth games, I still felt amused enough to see where everything was going and at what point they were going to subvert expectations. Here, half an hour in, my interest has already drifted off for greener pastures. If this improves as I play, I will edit this review, but... From what I've seen, I'm not exactly hopeful.

TL;DR: It's not exactly great, but if they fix the camera, you can ignore the terrible story and this game is worth a bash on a sale. If not...well...I hate to say this, but don't bother.

The story is pretty light so almost little to no knowledge of prior games is alright but you might miss out on little jokes here and there. The short levels make progress feel pretty good and the little in between scenes break up monotony with the usual 4th wall breaking humor. If you were looking for a game you can tackle at a leisurely pace this is your game. The only gripe I have is the lack of leveling grinding spots post game (the colosseum gets old after a while).
